{{*}}[[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] | awards = [[Military Cross]] | relations = | laterwork = }} Captain '''Maurice Douglas Guest Scott''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|MC}} (13 November 1895 – 17 March 1918) was a British World War I [[flying ace]] credited with [[List of World War I aces credited with 11–14 victories|twelve official victories]], including [[List of World War I aviators who shot down one observation balloon|one observation balloon]], while a member of the [[Royal Flying Corps]]. He scored as both an [[aerial observer]] and a pilot; he was successful while serving with three different squadrons.{{cite web |url=http://www.theaerodrome.com/aces/england/scott3.php |title=Maurice Douglas Guest Scott |work=The Aerodrome |year=2016 |accessdate=18 January 2016}} ==Early life== Scott was born in [[Mussoorie]], [[Bengal Presidency]], India, the second son of Philip William Scott (1865–1910), a civil engineer employed by the [[Eastern Bengal Railway]], and Agnes Mary (née Kirkham) (1865–1932). Following his father's death the family returned to England. In the 1911 census he is recorded as living in [[Bedford]] with his mother, his brother Percy (1893–1914), and his aunt Emily, but by 1914 the family were resident in [[Borrowash]], Derbyshire.{{cite web |url=http://unexaminedlives.org/guest-scott-maurice-d/ |title=Guest-Scott, Maurice D. |work=Unexamined Lives |year=2016 |accessdate=18 January 2016}} ==World War I service== After serving as a cadet in the [[Officers' Training Corps]],{{London Gazette |date=20 November 1914 |issue=28981 |startpage=9546 |endpage=9547}} Scott was commissioned as a temporary second lieutenant (on probation){{London Gazette |date=1 December 1914 |issue=28992 |startpage=10198 |nolink=yes}} in the 3rd Battalion, [[The Loyal North Lancashire Regiment]] on 14 November 1914.{{London Gazette |date=25 May 1915 |supp=yes |issue=29172 |startpage=5082 |nolink=yes}} He was confirmed in his rank on 1 October 1915.{{London Gazette |date=1 October 1915 |issue=29312 |startpage=9655 |nolink=yes}} Scott was seconded to the Royal Flying Corps in February 1916,{{sfnp|Franks|2005|p=22}} and after completing his aerial gunnery training was appointed a flying officer (observer) on 21 May.{{London Gazette |date=2 June 1916 |supp=yes |issue=29611 |startpage=5616 |nolink=yes}} He was posted to No. 18 Squadron to fly in the [[Vickers FB.5|Vickers Gunbus]] two-seater fighter. On 3 April 1916, he was credited with capturing a German two-seater reconnaissance aircraft at [[Souchez]]. He would subsequently train as a pilot, being appointed a [[flying officer]] on 16 October 1916, with seniority from 21 May.{{London Gazette |date=31 October 1916 |supp=yes |issue=29811 |startpage=10620 |nolink=yes}} He was then posted to No. 54 Squadron to fly the [[Sopwith Pup]] single-seat fighter. On 5 [[Bloody April|April 1917]], he shared with [[Frank Hudson]], [[Reginald Charley]], and another pilot, in the destruction of a German [[observation balloon]]. On 9 May 1917, he destroyed another enemy two-seater. Two days later, Scott shared with [[William Strugnell]], [[Oliver Sutton (aviator)|Oliver Sutton]], and three other squadron mates, in the destruction of an enemy reconnaissance aircraft. On 1 June, Scott and Sutton drove an [[Albatros D.III]] fighter down out of control over [[Honnecourt-sur-Escaut|Honnecourt]], and Scott became an ace. He subsequently transferred to No. 46 Squadron and was appointed a [[flight commander]], with the acting rank of captain, on 21 June 1917.{{London Gazette |date=3 July 1917 |supp=yes |issue=30163 |startpage=6646 |nolink=yes}} He began a string of seven wins on 4 September 1917, sharing with four others in the driving down of an Albatros two-seater south of Scarpe. He would gain six more wins that month, destroying a [[Deutsche Flugzeug-Werke|DFW]] reconnaissance aircraft, and driving down two Albatros D.Vs and two German reconnaissance aircraft. He was awarded the [[Military Cross]] on 27 October 1917.{{London Gazette |date=26 October 1917 |supp=yes |issue=30355 |startpage=11110 |nolink=yes}} On 8 October 1917, he was relieved from combat duty to return to Home Establishment, where on 1 November 1917 he was appointed a Group Instructor in Gunnery (graded as a flight commander).{{London Gazette |date=13 November 1917 |supp=yes |issue=30383 |startpage=11816 |nolink=yes}} Scott was killed in an flying accident at Shoreham, Sussex, on 17 March 1918, and is buried at [[All Saints' Church, Ockbrook|All Saints' Church]], [[Ockbrook]], [[Derbyshire]].{{CWGC|id=351812|name=Scott, Maurice Douglas Guest|access-date=18 January 2016}} ===List of aerial victories=== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%;" |- |+Combat record |- !No. ! width="130" |Date/Time ! width="100" |Aircraft/
